newsitem.title: USA: World Bank approves $550 million loans for Romania.
newsitem.headline: World Bank approves $550 million loans for Romania.

text.p: The World Bank said on Tuesday it approved a package of $550 million in loans to help Romania overhaul its economy and fight poverty.

The three loans -- $50 million to help the poor, $350 million for agricultural reform and $150 million to improve Romania's highways -- mark the beginning of new World Bank effort to provide the nation with major financial support.

"We are pleased with the vigorous steps the government has taken in proceeding swiftly with market reforms after the uneven progress in recent years," World Bank official Kenneth Lay said in a statement.

Romania earlier this year launched an economic shock therapy programme after a centrist-coalition ousted leftists in 1996 elections. Under the programme, the country has tightened monetary policies, liberalised fuel, energy and food prices and adopted an austerity budget.

Noting that poverty in Romania has increased five-fold since 1989, the World Bank said its $50 million social protection loan was aimed at helping the poor through the introduction of soup kitchens and other measures.
The $350 million credit for agricultural reform will help speed up privatisation of that sector and increase rural employment and living standards, it added.
The Bank will also provide an additional $150 million to revitalise Romania's roads.
The Bank credits follow a standby loan from the International Monetary Fund of $430 million approved in April to back up Romania's reforms.
Both the IMF and World Bank suspended credits for Romania last year after complaining that the leftist government then in power had overshot spending targets.
The Bank credits will be provided at market-related interest rates and will be repayable in 20 years.
